info.headline: Flood Advisory issued August 5 at 4:03PM EDT until August 5 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
info.description:
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall is expected.
* WHERE...A portion of southeastern York County, South Carolina.
* WHEN...Until 700 PM EDT.
* IMPACTS...Nuisance flooding of low-lying areas adjacent to streams and other poor-drainage areas, including farmland, parks, greenways, boat-access areas, golf courses, underpasses, and parking lots. Isolated, shallow flows over roadways is possible. A few flood-prone, low-water crossings may become impassible. A small culvert washout or two is possible.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 402 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicates that the heavy rainfall responsible for earlier flash flooding in York County has ended and additional significant rainfall is not expected for the remainder of today. Storm-total rainfall of 3-6 inches occurred between 4am and noon, resulting in excessive runoff and significant rises on numerous streams. Most streams have crested and are receding below bankfull levels. However, routed flow from upstream floodwaves are now impacting locations downstream of York and Rock Hill along Tools Fork Creek, Wildcat Creek, and Big Dutchmans Creek. Tools Fork Creek remains above Action Stage, resulting in nuisance flooding of adjacent low-lying areas. Earlier, Big Dutchmans Creek crested near 11.4 feet, above the Minor Flood Stage of 11.0 feet. Now, Big Dutchmans Creek is below Minor Flood Stage but above Action Stage, causing nuisance flooding of residential yards and wooded areas from West Oak Rd to Mt Gallant Rd. Meanwhile, Wildcat Creek near Robertson Rd is still rapidly rising toward 8 feet, but remains well below the Action Stage of 10 feet. It is possible Wildcat Creek will crest near 10 feet later over the next 1-2 hours.
Earlier, York County Emergency Management reported several secondary roads impacted by floodwaters. People are urged to obey all barricades, even if flood waters have receded, until crews can assess road safety.
Areas of ongoing concern include: 1) along Big Dutchman Creek in Rock Hill from India Hook Rd and Mt Gallant Rd near the Catawba River. 2) along Tools Fork Creek from SC 5 to SC 322 to Squire Rd. 3) along Wildcat Creek from Herlong Ave to SC 322 to Odgen Rd.
- Some locations that may continue to experience nuisance flooding include... Rock Hill, Newport, Lesslie, Catawba and Edgemoor. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
info.instruction:
Keep children away from storm drains, culverts, creeks and streams. Water levels can rise rapidly and sweep children away.
Stay away or be swept away. River banks and culverts can become unstable and unsafe.

parameter.value: FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 7 PM EDT THIS EVENING
